STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 6, 2025
Tracey Compton
UPPER PENINSULA FAMILY SOLUTIONS
369 US HIGHWAY 41 E,
NEGAUNEE, MI, 49866-9624
Re: License #: CB520304693
SI #: 2025SIC0000468
Dear Tracey Compton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any report violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
AMENDED
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000468
Special Investigation Intake Date: March 14, 2025
License #: CB520304693
Licensee Group Organization: Upper Peninsula Family Solutions
Licensee Designee: SANDRA SHELTROW
Chief Administrator: Tracey Compton
Agency Name: UPPER PENINSULA FAMILY SOLUTIONS
Agency Address: 369 US HIGHWAY 41 E
NEGAUNEE, MI 49866-9624
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 05/18/2026
II. METHODOLOGY

1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications
Section • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
Description suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency caseworker attempted to bully and insult a staff member
from another agency during a joint meeting regarding a youth in
common. In addition, agency caseworker made inappropriate
comments to youth regarding what may happen if he were to go to
detention or prison.
Investigation Hannahville Indian Community Tribal Probation Officer (HIC
Tribal PO) was interviewed via telephone on March 18, 2025.
She stated she attended a Team Decision Making (TDM) meeting
on March 4, 2025, regarding Youth A. The purpose of the meeting
was to discuss placement options. Youth A is currently in relative
placement with his grandparents, and they have asked for him to
be moved. She felt during the meeting Private Agency Foster
Care Foster Care Worker (PAFC FCW) and DHS staff were trying
to have Youth A placed in a residential detention through his
probation. She felt the group was trying to influence her to violate
his probation and place him through probation.
HIC Tribal PO stated she has been Youth A’s assigned probation
officer since October 2024. She reported Youth A has had
probation violations for having nicotine vapes and THC vapes and
testing positive for marijuana. The scoring on her assessment
indicates Youth A would benefit from community-based services
such as outpatient and in-home services, therefore she does not
feel residential is an appropriate option at this time. She stated
Youth A has gone through a lot and some recent changes have
upset him. His younger brother was moved from the same relative
home to a different home in another area, his older brother went to
jail, and his biological parents are in and out of his life. She stated
she feels Youth A has a lot of strengths and is hopeful he can
remain in the community and other community-based services be
considered.
HIC Tribal PO said PAFC FCW and Department of Health and
Human Services Purchase of Service Foster Care supervisor
(DHHS POS FC supervisor) were questioning probation during the
TDM, and she had to put her foot down. She indicated Youth A
2

has active consequences through probation that are being
followed through with. She had the impression the amount of
questioning toward probation was an attempt to have her place
Youth A in detention. HIC Tribal PO reported PAFC FCW was
informed HIC Tribal PO felt the communication during the TDM
was inappropriate and HIC Tribal PO felt cornered. PAFC FCW
contacted her and apologized and asked what remarks she felt
were upsetting. HIC Tribal PO reported to PAFC FCW that she felt
Youth A had consequences through probation and stated she felt
residential was not an appropriate fit for him and didn’t think he
would even meet criteria for residential or detention.
HIC Tribal PO was asked about the other allegations within the
complaint regarding inappropriate comments by PAFC FCW
toward Youth A. She stated during a phone call prior to the TDM
on March 4, 2025, PAFC FCW reported to her and Hannahville
Indian Community Social Services Director (HIC SS Director) that
while she was speaking to Youth A she told him he wouldn’t last in
prison because he’s too cute and there will be 5 guys on you.
Department of Health and Human Services Team Decision
Making Facilitator (DHHS TDM Facilitator) was interviewed via
Teams on March 19, 2025. He stated he was the TDM Facilitator
for a TDM held on March 4, 2025. Youth A is currently placed with
grandparents, and they have indicated they are no longer willing
to care for him due to his behaviors and the intention of the TDM
was to discuss placement options. DHHS TDM Facilitator did not
feel there was any bullying during the meeting. He felt things were
brought up in a straight to the point manner. Youth A has some
behavior challenges and there are not a lot of placement options
for him in the area. He felt PAFC FCW was straight to the point in
stating they don’t have a lot of options for him due to the not
having homes that could meet his needs or be willing to accept
placement. He stated the meeting was matter of fact, but he didn’t
feel it was contentious or heated. Overall, the concerns were
regarding Youth A’s incorrigibility or delinquency behaviors. If
Youth A isn’t held accountable for his actions, his behaviors will
continue regardless of his next placement. He stated in no way
was it done in a yelling/angry tone.
DHHS TDM Facilitator said during TDM’s all participants are
asked if they have any issues or concerns and if everyone is in
agreement and points out the goal of transparency and to give
everyone a chance to provide input. HIC Tribal PO was asked
about issues/concerns, and she didn’t speak up.
3

DHHS TDM Facilitator was asked about the other allegations
within the complaint regarding inappropriate comments by PAFC
FCW toward Youth A. He stated the comments regarding Youth A
being cute and pointing out what happens to cute boys in
detention is not something that was said during the TDM while he
was in attendance.
Department of Health and Human Services Purchase of
Service Foster Care Supervisor (DHHS POS FC supervisor)
was interviewed via telephone on March 19, 2025. She stated
she was in attendance during a TDM on March 4, 2025, to discuss
placement options/brainstorm for Youth A because relative
placement (grandparents) has indicated they can no longer care
for him due to his behaviors. DHHS POS FC supervisor stated
Youth A and his siblings have been in care for 44 months. The
biological parents are not working toward reunification and Youth
A’s behaviors have been challenging. The team at the TDM was
trying to come up with options for him and felt that everyone has
the same goal in mind for him. She stated none of the participants
were pointing fingers or blaming anyone and felt the group was
brainstorming a number of options. The team was trying to think
outside the box due to the ongoing placement crisis and level of
difficulty regarding Youth A due to his behaviors. Conversation
took place to preserve the current placement with relatives and
the possibility of keeping him there with tighter reins.
During the meeting PAFC FCW did indicate there haven’t been
consequences for Youth A’s probation, but it wasn’t in the context
that the tribe isn’t doing anything about it. Youth A continues to
have positive drug screens. She didn’t get the impression there
was any bullying. During the meeting it was pointed out the length
of time Youth A has been on probation, the number of violations
he has had and the overall lack of consequences. HIC Tribal PO
was the only representative from the tribe and there were some
questions directed about what the tribal judge could do or tribal
probation. There were several ideas that were brought up and
discussed. She freely admitted that she would acknowledge if she
witnessed any inappropriate behavior and that was not the case
during the time she participated in the TDM. She clarified that she
had to sign off the meeting early and thinks she missed the last 40
minutes of the meeting.
DHHS POS FC supervisor was asked about the other allegations
within the complaint regarding inappropriate comments by PAFC
FCW toward Youth A. She stated she has no knowledge of any
4

inappropriate comments made by PAFC FCW toward or about
Youth A.
Department of Health and Human Services Purchase of
Service Foster Care worker (DHHS POS FCW) was
interviewed via telephone on March 25, 2025. She stated she
was present at the TDM that was held on March 4, 2025,
regarding Youth A. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss
placement options for Youth A as his relative caregiver has
advised he needs to be moved from their home due to extensive
ongoing behaviors. She stated she did not feel PAFC FCW was
inappropriate or displayed any bullying behavior during the
meeting. There was a level of frustration as there was no
resolution after a lengthy meeting and no official plans put in
place. During the TDM there was discussion regarding what can
be done to maintain current placement with relative caregiver and
if that isn’t possible what options are available to keep him in the
community including another relative placement or fictive kin.
There was also discussion that if the other options are not
possible, there is a chance he will end up in a placement
downstate. Part of the discussion included what options may be
available through his probation since he has continued to violate
the terms of his probation.
DHHS POS FCW was asked about the other allegations within the
complaint regarding inappropriate comments by FCW toward
Youth A. She is not aware of any comments made to Youth A
regarding his appearance and what could happen if he ends up in
detention or prison.
Community Mental Health Wraparound Coordinator (CMH
Wraparound Coordinator) was interviewed via telephone on
March 25, 2025. She stated she is the Wraparound Coordinator
for Youth A and has worked with the family for a little over 2 years.
She attended the entire TDM (almost 2.5 hours) regarding Youth
A on March 4, 2025. She stated Youth A has struggled with
behavioral issues and has not been adhering to his probation
requirements and the purpose of the TDM was to determine if it
was possible to preserve current placement with relatives and if
not, explore other placements options.
She stated she has worked with PAFC FCW many times and
didn’t view her behavior during the TDM as being unprofessional.
She was attempting to come up with multiple placement options
for Youth A and was passionate in her efforts. She clarified due to
staffing issues, PAFC FCW doesn’t normally take on case
5

management as she is the Director of the agency, so people
aren’t used to working with her and observing her style. She didn’t
observe any tension between PAFC FCW and any of the
participants of the meeting including tribal staff.
She stated she was not under the impression that PAFC FCW
was threatening to have Youth A sent downstate if the tribal
employee didn’t agree to certain actions. It was more if this
doesn’t happen, we will have to consider placement options in
other areas of the state due to limited options in the Upper
Peninsula (UP). There is a good chance if a placement is located
it will be downstate.
There was a court hearing held last week in tribal court regarding
Youth A. He is failing most of his classes, failing drug screens and
not adhering to other aspects of his probation. The probation
violations do not rise to the level of requiring detention. HIC Tribal
PO did an assessment through probation and that also
determined Youth A does not meet criteria for detention and could
benefit from community-based services instead. PAFC FCW
updated the court with the efforts to maintain current placement
and also locate another family member, fictive kin and licensed
foster placement. Family members are willing to take him for
respite only but nothing long term. CMH Wraparound Coordinator
made the recommendation in court to consider Great Lakes
Recovery Adolescent to address his substance abuse since this is
an issue and Youth A has acknowledged the issue and also his
need for help. The judge liked the idea, and the team is trying to
see if that is possible.
CMH Wraparound Coordinator was asked about the other
allegations within the complaint regarding inappropriate comments
by PAFC FCW toward Youth A. She stated she did not have any
knowledge of inappropriate comments made by PAFC FCW
toward Youth A. She stated she meets with Youth A on a weekly
basis, and he has not said anything about PAFC FCW saying
things that he found to be upsetting or inappropriate.
Private Agency Foster Care Foster Care Supervisor (PAFC FC
supervisor) was interviewed via telephone on March 27, 2025.
She stated there was a lengthy TDM held on March 4, 2025, to
discuss placement options for Youth A. Prior to the TDM there
was a phone call between PAFC FCW, HIC Tribal PO, HIC SS
Director and PAFC CW supervisor. It is her understanding, based
on what PAFC FCW reported to her, the conversation revolved
6

around whether or not Youth A could be determined as an Act 150
which may open up additional placement options.
PAFC FC supervisor stated the purpose of the TDM was to
brainstorm and come up with possible options for Youth A. She
clarified Youth A has been in relative placement for over 3 years
and they have asked for him to be moved due to ongoing
behavioral issues. She felt the tone of the meeting was a team
coming together with the same goal in mind to come up with
options for placement. Throughout the meeting the team
discussed many potential placement options. It was also
discussed that the consequences from probation have not had an
impact on Youth A but it was not addressed in a way that placed
blame on anyone or entity in particular or done in a threatening
manner. The reality of being in a rural area and a lack of
placement options overall but specifically for older youth with
behavioral issues was also discussed and the team may need to
consider placement options downstate.
PAFC FC supervisor was asked about the other allegations within
the complaint regarding inappropriate comments toward Youth A.
She stated PACF FCW reported to her after her home visit with
Youth he was repeatedly making threatening statements about
wanting to kill his mother’s boyfriend. PAFC FC supervisor stated
PAFC FCW reported attempting to caution Youth A that jail/prison
is not a place he would want to be and everything seemed to be a
joke to Youth A. PAFC FCW told Youth A that he was cute and in
prison 5 guys would hold you down. PAFC FC supervisor stated
she wasn’t concerned by the comment based on the context of the
entire conversation and it was an attempt to reason with Youth A
so he could see the potential consequences of committing that
type of violent act.
Relative Caregiver was interviewed via telephone on March
31, 2025. She stated she attended the TDM that was held on
March 4, 2025. She stated PAFC FCW has been nothing short of
fabulous and she in no way was inappropriate or displayed any
bullying behavior during the meeting. PAFC FCW indicated during
the meeting relative caregivers have stated they are no longer
able to provide placement due to Youth A’s ongoing behaviors, so
the meeting revolved around trying to come up with other ideas to
maintain placement or find something to keep him in the area.
There was discussion regarding the UP being more rural and less
placement options so if there isn’t another option Youth A may
need to be placed in a foster home or detention downstate. It was
7

not stated in a threatening manner but more as this is where we’re
at because we don’t have any other options.
Relative Caregiver stated Youth A has been in her and her
husband’s care for 3.5 years. Youth A and his younger brother’s
behaviors have been out of control, and it is partially due to
biological parents coming in and out of their lives or seeing them
in the community. She became emotional when discussing
reaching the decision for Youth A and his younger brother to be
moved from their home. She feels frustrated because PAFC FCW
has been wonderful to work with and she was run out due to the
stress of the complaints and difficult interactions. She expressed
further frustration regarding the lack of consequences for Youth A
while he has been on probation. She clarified Youth A is failing all
of his classes and hasn’t passed a drug screen since the end of
October and there have been little to no consequences.
Relative caregiver was asked about the other allegations within
the complaint regarding inappropriate comments by PAFC FCW
toward Youth A. She stated PAFC FCW reported the conversation
to her after meeting with Youth A and indicated she made
comments to that effect however it was taken out of context.
Youth A was mad because he found out his mother went back to
her ex-boyfriend who he doesn’t like. He made a comment that he
was going to kill him or have someone else kill him. PAFC FCW
advised Youth A that wouldn’t be smart move and would end up in
prison. Youth A was puffing up his chest and acting like he could
handle himself in prison and PAFC FCW repeated that he would
end up in prison and prison is not a place for you as you know
what happens to cute boys in prison. Youth A continued repeating
the threats and she was trying to get him to realize that because
of his good looks prison life would be very different than what his
perception is and if he would to follow through on the threats that’s
where he would end up. She stated she is very protective of her
grandkids and if she thought for one-minute PAFC FCW had said
or done anything that was inappropriate she would have
immediately spoken up and addressed it. In her opinion it was
appropriate based on the context of the conversation and knowing
Youth A. She clarified when he is escalated it can be very difficult
to have a conversation with him and to get him to hear the
message you are conveying. Youth A was not upset and never
brought it up to her. She stated the conversation occurred during
the home visit in either February or March.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on March 27, 2025. He
was asked if there was an incident recently where he and PAFC
8

FCW had a discussion about what would happen if he would to go
to prison or detention and what could happen. He indicated he
wasn’t sure, so he was specifically asked about a conversation
where he made statements, he wanted to kill his mother’s
boyfriend after learning he had been physically abusive and there
was a history of physical abuse. He recalled the conversation but
stated he couldn’t recall details. He was asked if PAFC FCW
made a comment that he was “cute and what could happen to him
if he were to go to prison or detention” He stated he does not
recall those comments. He was asked the question a second time
later in the interview and he said he recalled PAFC FCW stating in
general terms that going to prison or detention wouldn’t be a good
thing and it’s not a good place to be. It was more a cautionary
statement and nothing inappropriate.
He stated there has never been a time where PAFC FCW said
anything inappropriate to him or made him uncomfortable. He
clarified he always felt comfortable talking with PAFC FCW. He
stated if she had ever made any statements that were
inappropriate or made him uncomfortable, he would have spoken
up. He identified he has other people in his life that he would be
comfortable reporting if anything inappropriate occurred or made
him uncomfortable.
PAFC FCW was interviewed via telephone on April 3, 2025.
She has been the assigned foster care worker for Youth A and his
siblings since August 2024. She stated there was a TDM on
March 4, 2025, regarding Youth A to discuss placement options.
Due to Youth A’s escalating behaviors, relative caregivers had
previously asked for him to be removed from their home. He has
displayed verbal aggression to relative caregiver. PAFC FCW
stated, at times, Youth A will become so escalated that it’s best to
let it play out because if you try and diffuse, he escalates even
more. He is struggling significantly with school and failing his
classes. The purpose of the TDM was to discuss different relative
options, funding options and other non-relative options. She stated
she doesn’t feel she came across as bullying or verbally
aggressive. She stated she wasn’t at all angry at the meeting. She
felt it was a gathering of individuals who have the same goal in
mind regarding Youth A and trying to troubleshoot ideas and come
up with a plan for placement. She acknowledged that sometimes
she talks fast and can be blunt but could not think of any time
during the meeting where she was inappropriate in any way
especially with other members of the meeting.
9

Prior to the TDM she was speaking with Private Agency Foster
Care Child Welfare supervisor (PAFC Child Welfare supervisor)
who was previously employed in Juvenile Justice at MDHHS.
They were discussing placement options for Youth A and PAFC
Child Welfare supervisor stated in the past they used to commit
youth as Act 150’s. They then called HIC SS Director and HIC
Tribal PO to discuss this as a possibility. The purpose of the call
was to discuss placement options for Youth A. PAFC FCW was
asking questions in order to determine if Act 150 was an
appropriate route or not. She felt the meeting went through with no
concerns and there was no mention of anyone being upset. At one
point, HIC SS Director made the comment that they need to hold
their youth more accountable through probation.
PAFC FCW stated she called HIC Tribal PO after being told she
was upset after the TDM. She offered an apology for hurting her
feelings and inquired about what she had said that made her
upset and HIC Tribal PO said PAFC FCW made the comment that
probation wasn’t doing anything for Youth A. PAFC FCW stated
she told HIC Tribal PO that she meant probation in general and
not HIC Tribal PO specifically doesn’t help or care. She
apologized for the poor choice of words and thought it had been
settled. She then called HIC SS Director and left a voicemail
apologizing for upsetting HIC Tribal PO and asked for a return
phone call, but she has not received a return phone call. PAFC
FCW was adamant that she was not inappropriate in any way
during the meeting and feels she did not do anything to warrant a
complaint. She stated during the meeting she made a comment
that if they can’t come up with a viable placement option Youth A
will end up downstate. She clarified that wasn’t a threat but the
reality of the situation. Placement is difficult and it’s even more
difficult to locate placement for a teenager who has behavioral
issues in a rural area. She stated HIC SS Director stated, “well
that happens sometimes with our kids”.
PAFC FCW was asked about the other allegations within the
complaint regarding inappropriate comments toward Youth A.
PAFC FCW stated during a home visit on March 1, 2025, she held
a private meeting with Youth A and was discussing his school
struggles, and he became upset. At some point during the
conversation, he began talking about his mother’s boyfriend and
how he was going to kill him because he is physically abusive
towards his mother. She stated Youth A went into detail about
how he planned on killing mother’s boyfriend making statements
about having access to guns and knowing people who would help.
She stated he made the same threat at least 3 times during the
10

conversation. She tried to reason with Youth A by stating that isn’t
something you want to do and asked if he wanted to end up in
prison for the rest of his life. Youth A made a comment that he’s
strong and would do fine if he were to go to prison and she said
and you’re “cute” and he repeated that he was strong. She stated
you aren’t going to be strong if 6 men are holding you down. She
stated Youth A did not have a reaction and again indicated he
would just assault his mother’s boyfriend. She said conversation
continued for a little while regarding possible legal consequences.
PAFC FCW stated she doesn’t feel Youth A would’ve followed
through on the threat at that point but expressed concern as he
became older due to struggling to regulate his emotions and lack
of insight on consequences and what that could look like for him.
She referenced the conversation to others because she was so
concerned about the threats Youth A was making. She stated she
didn’t feel it was inappropriate based on the context of the
conversation and how it flowed and his perception of prison and
what the experience could be like for him.
PAFC Child Welfare supervisor was interviewed via telephone
on April 4, 2025. She stated she was not part of the TDM on
March 4, 2025, but prior to the TDM she participated in a phone
call that included PAFC FCW, HIC Tribal PO, and HIC SS
Director. PAFC Child Welfare supervisor stated she was
previously a Juvenile Justice worker at MDHHS. The purpose of
the meeting was to brainstorm to determine placement options
and if Youth A could be an Act 150.
She felt the conversation was civil and never contentious. HIC SS
Director wasn’t aware of what an Act 150 was, so PAFC Child
Welfare supervisor explained what that meant. There were no
comments that indicated tribal staff were not doing their jobs. The
conversation included some placement options but also cautioned
that if there isn’t a resolution he will probably have to be moved
downstate due to the limited placement options in the UP.
PAFC Child Welfare supervisor was asked about the other
allegations within the complaint regarding inappropriate comments
by PAFC FCW toward Youth A. She stated during the meeting
with the tribe PAFC FCW updated them on her recent meeting
with Youth A. She reported she had recently met with Youth A and
was concerned due to his escalating behaviors and making
threats about wanting to murder people. PAFC FCW reported
Youth A believes he’s untouchable and there will not be
consequences if he follows through on the threats he was making.
She reported telling Youth A something to the effect “you’re not
11

strong enough to deal with 6 people holding you down.” She
doesn’t recall any reaction regarding that statement during the
call.
Maternal Uncle was interviewed via telephone on April 4,
2025. He stated he attended the TDM on March 4, 2025,
regarding placement options for Youth A. He stated he did not
witness any behavior that he would consider inappropriate or
bullying.
Maternal Uncle was asked about the other allegations within the
complaint regarding inappropriate comments by PAFC FCW
toward Youth A. He stated he has no knowledge of the other
allegations.
Hannahville Indian Community Social Services Director (HIC
SS Director) was interviewed via telephone on April 11, 2025.
She stated a TDM was held on March 4, 2025, to discuss
placement options for Youth A. Youth A is currently residing with
Relative Caregiver but they have asked that he be moved. HIC SS
Director clarified she was not present at the TDM however HIC
Tribal PO was. Prior to the TDM on March 4, 2025, HIC Tribal PO
had been on a phone call with PAFC FCW. While on the phone
call she walked into her office and HIC SS Director then joined the
call. During the call PAFC FCW stated the tribe needs to get
Youth A committed to a facility and they are able to do that
through Act 150. HIC SS Director indicated during the call that she
is not familiar with Act 150 and that isn’t how their process works.
At that point, PAFC FCW stated it will be the tribe’s responsibility
when Youth A ends up being moved downstate and continued to
be argumentative regarding what the tribe is and is not able to do
regarding Youth A’s placement. She acknowledged Youth A can
be challenging but stated the tribe doesn’t feel Youth A’s
behaviors warrant being sent to detention at this time. She feels
PAFC FCW already made up her mind that the only option for
Youth A is detention and isn’t considering other less restrictive
options.
HIC SS Director clarified she was not present at the TDM however
HIC Tribal PO was. She reported HIC Tribal PO was very upset
after the TDM and stated she didn’t wish to participate in a similar
meeting if this is how they go and was visibly red in the face. HIC
SS Director stated HIC Tribal PO felt, in general, she was ganged
up on. Overall, she felt singled out and attacked. She expressed
frustration because there has been a lot of effort to build up the
relationship between DHHS, the tribe and private agency to work
12

together. She stated she recognizes PAFC FCW isn’t typically
assigned to cases as the case manager. She feels PAFC FCW
needs to be more aware of her tone and choice of words moving
forward when working with youth who have experienced trauma.
In addition, knowing when it’s appropriate to back down on the
conversation if a youth becomes escalated and revisit the topic
later or in a different way that would be more receptive.
HIC SS Director was asked about the other allegations within the
complaint regarding inappropriate comments by PAFC FCW
toward Youth A. During the phone conversation with PAFC FCW,
PAFC Child Welfare supervisor, HIC Tribal PO and herself that
took place prior to the TDM, PAFC FCW was describing an
interaction she had with Youth A during a home visit. PAFC FCW
stated she told Youth A how cute he was, and you know what they
do to cute boys in prison and then proceeded to make a comment
about 6 men holding him down. HIC SS Director stated PAFC
FCW reported she was discussing Youth A’s behaviors with him
and how he can become aggressive, and his behavior could land
him in jail, and this is what would happen to him if he went to jail.
HIC SS Director stated she is in full agreement that youth should
be made aware of potential consequences if they break the law
however she felt the way PAFC FCW went about it was not
appropriate.
Documents reviewed:
• FTM held on March 4, 2025, TDM. Summary of meeting:
Meeting discussed placement options, options for services,
and behaviors of the children. Concerns expressed are how
difficult placement would be for the children and to keep the
children together. Both siblings have had behavioral issues
that have led to the current relative providers indicating that
they are not able to continue with placement. Variety of
options discussed, and more discussion is needed.
March 1, 2025, social work contact from home visit with
PAFC FCW, Youth A and Relative Caregiver. Private
meeting between Youth A and PAFC FCW. “Youth A made
comments about killing his mother's boyfriend because he
physically abuses her. After further discussion regarding the
consequences of murder, he discussed assaulting the man.
Youth A believes that if he simply assaults this man he will
not get caught. Youth A does not believe he has behavioral
issues and justifies all of his actions. He has never
considered that his placement may not be maintained
because of his behaviors”.
13

• April 1, 2025, tribal court order regarding Youth A. “The
needs of the child cannot be met in a foster home.
Placement of the child in a qualified residential treatment
program provides the most effective and appropriate level
of care for the child in the least restrictive environment and
is consistent with the goals in the permanency plan for the
child”.
Analysis In regard to the initial portion of the complaint regarding PAFC
FCW displaying aggressive and bullying behavior towards HIC
Tribal PO during a TDM, the agency is in compliance. Although it
is acknowledged HIC Tribal PO felt pressured and bullied, based
upon completed interviews with attendees of the TDM, there is no
evidence to support the allegation PAFC FCW behaved
inappropriately.
In regard to the second portion of the complaint regarding PAFC
FCW making an inappropriate comment to Youth A during a home
visit, the agency is found in noncompliance. Although PAFC FCW
was trying to caution Youth A on potential consequences of
committing violent acts, the comment made was not appropriate,
especially when working with youth in care who have experienced
trauma.
Conclusion Violation Established
14

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the current license status be continued.
